conbody.p: The recommended deployment architecture includes the following characteristics:

ul.li:
The primary and secondary nodes each have two NICs, with one NIC dedicated to disk synchronization via DRBD, and the other NIC dedicated to and application traffic.
Two NICs on each HA cluster node allows separation of network traffic required for disk synchronization (DRBD) from that required by the application itself. This configuration results in more up-to-date disk synchronization and better network responsiveness from and the application it is managing.
If both nodes in the high-availability cluster have two NICs, the traffic for each NIC must be routed through separate subnets.
Application services are deployed on dedicated resource pool hosts outside of the high-availability cluster.
Fencing is employed on production high-availability clusters.

conbody.p: If you do not have two identical, dual-NIC machines available, it is still possible to deploy an HA cluster with single-NIC servers. Use two hosts for the master host, where the two are configured in an active/passive configuration. You will use these two hosts only to run itself. Do not use them to run application services. Plan to deploy at least two additional resource pool hosts. Only the master hosts will be configured in an active/passive cluster.

Fencing is a critical consideration. Fencing is a technique to ensure that a failed node in the cluster is completely stopped. This technique avoids situations where runaway processes on the failed node continue trying to use shared resources, resulting in application conflicts or conflicts with the cluster management software.

Fencing is recommended for production environments; however administrators who want to stand up an initial test deployment of a high-availability cluster can do so without fencing, and then add fencing later. Many fencing solutions are available, making it impractical for to document solutions for every possible scenario. To implement a fencing solution that works for their particular infrastructure, the administrators must work with their IT departments.
